policy_summary:
All eviction proceedings requiring compliance with the Landlord and Tenant Act of 1951 and the Manufactured Home Community Rights Act cannot commence for 60 days until July 10, 2020.

All foreclosures requiring compliance with Act 6 and Act 91 cannot commence for 60 days until July 10, 2020. All foreclosure timelines must be computed with a start date of July 10, 2020, at which point any previously delivered Act 6 and Act 91 notices will be deemed delivered andany foreclosure process may commence.
state_level_legal_summary: The Governor issued an executive order preventing the filing of an eviction and tolling any evictions for 60 days until July 10, 2020. The Supreme Court of Pennysylvania initially placed a freeze on eviction proceedings and judgments through 5/1/20. Supplemental orders have extended this to 5/11/20, after which time the suspension of these proceeings "shall cease."

policy_summary: Moratorium on eviction for nonpayment of rent until the date the governor determines, under sec. 2 of this Act, that the public health disaster emergency no longer exists, or until June 30, 2020, whichever is earlier.
state_level_legal_summary: On March 13, the State Supreme Court placed a moratorium on all non-emergency cases including most civil cases, which implicitly applied evictions. This was made explicit by an administrative order issued by the Presiding Judges of four judicial districts in Alaska, which stated that all eviction hearings woiuld be suspended during the duration of general civil case moratorium and gave judges discretion to stay issued eviction orders due to sickness, quarantine, or self-quarantine during the coronavirus crisis. On April 24, the Court resumed evictions not covered under the Governor's executive order or the CARES Act moratorium. The Governor also announced an executive order that would suspend evictions for tenants who recieve rental assistance through the Alaska Housing Finance Corporation, as well as directing the AHFC to suspend foreclosures and evictions. Some localities have suspended utility and water shutoffs. In April, the legislature suspended any statute that would give a cause of action for evictions or foreclosures, but only as it applies to tenants or mortgagees experiencing financial hardship due to COVID-19. The legislation also suspended utility disconnection due to COVID-19 hardship and provided homeless prevention funding.

policy_summary: Alameda County closed its Eviction Court until April 7th and the Sheriff’s Department suspended all eviction enforcement for the time being. On April 21, the Board of Supervisors strengthened its existing ordinance to include a moratorium on evictions for non-payment of rent and no-fault reasons during the state of emergency. This applies to tenants and homeowners alike. For tenants who are financially impacted by the coronavirus crisis, the ordinance allows a 12-month repayment period without late fees. At the end of 12 months, any remaining back rent is converted into a consumer debt. But impacted tenants can never be evicted for their inability to pay rent during the emergency period. In order to qualify for these protections, tenants must provide documentation or a sworn statement demonstrating financial hardship within 45 days of receiving a request from their landlord or 30 days of the end of the state of emergency, whichever is later. These protections extend to all cities and unincorporated areas of the County alike. This means that renters in cities that have not passed local ordinances, like Dublin, are now protected by the County ordinance. In cities with local ordinances, however, residents are protected by the stronger of the two laws.
state_level_legal_summary: The Judicial Council of California adopted emergency rules preventing the issuance of summons and the entry of default in all foreclosure and eviction cases, including commercial, unless there is a threat to public health. The rules also postpone trials for at least 60 days. The Governor has issued an executive order banning the enforcement of eviction orders, and tolling response time for new eviction complaints, for renters affected by COVID-19 through May 31, 2020. This order still allows for local governments to pass their own stricter eviction bans. Since the Governor had previously issued an order giving local governments authority to halt evictions, slow foreclosures, and protect against utility shutoffs, several local governments have adopted coronavirus-specific eviction restrictions. Most of these require tenants to provide documentation to verify that they are unable to pay rent due to financial impacts related to COVID-19. Many county superior courts are tolling deadlines via emergency order.

policy_summary: Moratorium on evictions for residential tenants for most types of evictions (including Ellis Act, but not evictions related to violence, threats of violence, health or safety issues). Also provides for extensions for non-medical reasons. Tenants have 30 days after date rent is due to notify landlords in writing of inability to pay EACH TIME (e.g., every month), and must document inability to pay within 7 days of providing that notice. Tenant automatically receives an additional 30 days to pay. If the tenant then fails to pay, landlord must: (i) inform the tenant in writing of the breach and attempt in good faith to develop a payment plan. Ultimately, the tenant will have up to 6 months following termination of the emergency declaration to repay any back-due rent. The process is outlined here. Moratorium on evictions of commercial tenants licensed to operate in San Francisco and with less than $25 million in annual gross receipts. Tenants have 3 months after the expiration of the Local Emergency to pay back rent. Landlords cannot charge interest or late fees during the Local Emergency Period. 3/15/20 Mayor Breed Executive Order imposing a temporary moratorium on eviction for non-payment of rent by residential tenants directly impacted by the novel coronavirus crisis. Effective during the state of emergency. 3/17/20 Mayor Breed Executive Order for Commercial Tenants effective during the state of emergency.

policy_summary: Governor has issued a temporary moratorium on all commerical and residential evictions and prohibits law enforcement from enforcing past orders of eviction. Provides an exception for cases where a landlord/owner can show that eviction is necessary for a public health or safety reason. Late fees cannot be assessed; rent cannot be raised until 6/4
state_level_legal_summary: The Governor of Washington issued a temporary moratorium on all commerical and residential evictions and prohibits law enforcement from enforcing past orders of eviction. The Governor's Proclamation provides an exception for cases where a landlord/owner can show that eviction is necessary for a public health or safety reason.The Governor's order also prohibits property owners from assessing late fees. Seattle has extended eviction protections for 6 months after the state's moratorium expires.

policy_summary: Supreme Court of the Virgin Islands stayed all orders of eviction and foreclosure until 6/1/20. Filings are essential service and will continue to be allowed.
state_level_legal_summary: The Supreme Court of the Virgin Islands stayed all orders of eviction and foreclosure not yet executed until 4/27/20. Filings are essential service and will continue to be allowed.

policy_summary: All civil trials are suspended and will be rescheduled after June 5. This should include evictions, although the order does not mention them explicitly.

policy_summary: The Supreme Court of Guam has suspended all civil cases through 6/5/20. The Governor of Guam issued an emergency declaration prohibiting the initiation of any eviction or foreclosure actions involving real estate or property, whether rental or otherwise and tolled eviction and foreclosure actions currently in process for the duration of the public health emergency. The order does not clearly halt execution of past orders of eviction.
state_level_legal_summary: The Supreme Court of Guam has suspended all civil and criminal cases and tolled filing deadlines through 4/15/20. The Governor of Guam issued an emergency declaration prohibiting the initiation of any eviction or foreclosure actions involving real estate or property, whether rental or otherwise and tolled eviction and foreclosure actions currently in process for the duration of the public health emergency. The order does not clearly halt execution of past orders of eviction.

policy_summary: The DC Superior Court suspended landlord tenant and civil cases and stayed eviction and foreclosure cases until at least May 1. The D.C. Council passed emergency legislation prohibiting evictions and late fees during the time period for which the Mayor has declared a public health emergency, which is until at least May 15. The legislation also prohibits utility shutoffs.
state_level_legal_summary: The DC Superior Court suspended landlord tenant and civil cases and stayed eviction and foreclosure cases until at least May 15. The D.C. Council passed emergency legisliation prohibiting filing and execution of evictions, foreclosures, and late fees during the time period for which the Mayor has declared a public health emergency. The legislation also prohibits utility shutoffs and requires a COVID-19 hardship alert on any consumer report. If a property has 5 or more units, property owners must offer tenants a payment plan program for past due rent and cannot report any tenant participating in the program to collections.

policy_summary: Suspends hearings on evictions except in emergency landlord tenant hearings
state_level_legal_summary: The Supreme Court of Vermont had suspended all non-emergency civil cases, at the discretion of the judge but ordered hearings resume on June 1. State lawmakers passed and the governor signed on May 14 emergency legislation that stays evictions cases, orders and executions until the end of the emergency.

policy_summary: The Chief Administrative Judge of the State of New York Unified Court System's 3/15/20 memorandum states that "all eviction proceedings and pending eviction orders shall be suspended statewide until further notice." The Chief Administrative Judge had initially issued a one-week moratorium in New York City on 3/13/20. There will be no evictions of any kind, for anyone, as long as the 3/15/20 moratorium is in place. In NYC, all city marshals have been notified that they cannot execute any pre-existing warrants. Outside of NYC, law enforcement entities should have been notified by the local courts. The Governor's 3/20/20 Executive Order declared an eviction and foreclosure morotorium for 90 days. On 5/7/20, the Governor issued an Executive Order that allows tenants to use their security deposit to pay past rent, prohibits late fees, prohibits eviction for nonpayment due to COVID-19 hardship for a period of 60 days beginning on June 20, and prohibits any fee or charge for late payment of rent occurring during the time period from March 20, 2020 through August 20, 2020. Right to Counsel is calling on the Governor to issue a REAL extension of the eviction moratorium for ALL tenants for as long as the crisis lasts. Call Cuomo and your state representatives to demand this TODAY!

policy_summary: On April 22, Governor Bullock extended his directive that protects all tenants in Montana from eviction for nonpayment through at least May 24, 2020. If you are a "vulnerable" person, then the Governor's directive may last longer. You are considered a "vulnerable" person if you remain sheltered at home and are: over 65, or have a serious underlying health condition (including high blood pressure, chronic lung disease, diabetes, obesity, or asthma), or have an immune system that is compromised, such as by chemotherapy. If you are a "vulnerable" person, then the Governor's directive will not expire for you until the earliest of these dates: 30 days after you stop sheltering at home, or the end of the Covid-19 emergency. Previously, on April 13, Governor Bullock issued a new directive authorizing funds for Montana tenants who lack money for rent or security deposits because of COVID-19.
state_level_legal_summary: Montana Governor Steve Bullock issued an order on March 30th prohibiting landlords from terminating a lease or refusing to renew/ extend the terms of a current lease agreement, at least on a month-to-month basis. This order was extended through April 24th but also significantly limited. The new order provides for a rental assistance program, but limits the eviction protections of the first order to tenants under quarantine, self-quarantine, or experiencing loss of inclome due to COVID-19.The governor's order also prohibits suspension of utilities during the emergency, including electricity, gas, sewage disposal, water, telephone, or internet services, and prohibits late fees for bills due. The Supreme Court of Montana supsended all civil cases.

policy_summary: Maryland has both gubernatorial and court orders staying evictions; the governor's order states that evictions should not issue if the tenant is subject to financial hardship due to COVID-19, while the State Supreme Court order is broader and stays pending evictions and foreclosure cases without this condition.The state has suspended utility shutoffs. Almost all (but not all) counties have also issued orders to sheriffs directing them not to enforce any eviction orders. Many counties have also stayed commercial evictions, subject to emergency motion arguing the stay presents an undue burden. The American Civil Liberties Union of Maryland, the Homeless Persons Representation Project and the Public Justice Center, sent a letter to the governor urging him to expand the prohibitions by using more than $153 million in federal funds from the Coronavirus Aid, Relief and Economic Security (CARES) Act.

policy_summary: Maine's Judicial Branch ordered that effective on March 18, 2020 through May 1, 2020, all evictions and foreclosures are suspended; previously scheduled cases will not be heard and new cases will not be scheduled for a hearing until May 1. Governor Mills issued an order prohibiting writs of restitution from being executed except in cases of imminent risk of harm or criminal activity, and extending the time by which a notice has to be given to terminate a tenancy at will. The state also issued a statewide moratorium on utility shutoffs. No specific courts, cities, or counties are known to have made separate or additional orders to supplement the statewide order. To our knowledge, tolling has not been suspended in the state of Maine.

policy_summary: Governor Laura Kelly has declared that eviction and foreclosure proceedings cannot be brought as a result of nonpayment due to financial hardship related to COVID-19; if an eviction is filed, the plaintiff must prove that it's not being brought only because of such financial hardship. Courts in Kansas are conducting only essential functions in person, which do not appear to include evictions and foreclosures; however, the court states that nonessential functions may still move forward to the extent local resources allow.

policy_summary: Declares eviction actions shall not be brought; tolls deadlines in ongoing eviction actions until at least 31 days after emergency ends; states that writs may not be executed.
state_level_legal_summary: Governor John Carney issued a comprehensive executive order establishing moratoriums for evictions, foreclosures, and utility shutoffs during the duration of the Covid-19 crisis. The order prevents new filings, tolls deadlines in pending cases until 31 days after the emergency ends, and prevents execution of issued judgments, and prohibits landlords from charging late fees. It also prevents new foreclosure actions, tolls deadlines in ongoing foreclosure cases, and prevents sheriff sales and the execution of writs of possession until 31 days after the emergency ends. The Justice of the Peace Court has also ordered that all landlord/tenant cases and ordered/scheduled evictions between March 17 and April 16 be delayed until after May 1, with exceptions for "landlord-tenant matters involving essential services and/or harm to persons or property."

policy_summary: Governor Kate Brown has strengthened previous orders. As of April 1, there is a 90-day moratorium on serving evictions to commercial and residential tenants. The order only bars police from enforcing evictions due to nonpayment of rent for a period of ninety days, but evictions for failing a rental inspection, noise complaints or any other thing deemed as a lease violation may still be served. The order makes no space for a longer repayment schedule while numerous banks have publicly given 12-month extensions to their mortgage holders, nor does this order address the need for a Nationwide Rent Freeze or Suspension to keep out of work renters from accruing mass amounts of debt.
state_level_legal_status: Eviction Cases & Nonpayment Eviction Enforcement Suspended
state_level_legal_summary: The Chief Judge of Oregon postponed all first appearances and trials for evictions, and many county circuit courts postponed all eviction related matters. The Governor of Oregon issued Executive Order No. 20-11, which places a temporary moratorium on execution of residential evictions related to non-payment; and Executive Order No. 20-13, which places a temporary moratorium on landlord terminations of residential rental agreements and non-residential leases. The Governor's order also prohibits charging late fees. Most counties and some cities have also limited the eviction moratorium to non-payment cases, and a few have extended it to no-cause evictions. Under the Chief Judge's order, while hearings and proceedings for civil cases are generally postponed, the cases with statutory or constitutional mandates requiring them to be held during the moratorium period will still continue. All judicial districts have postponed jury trials and are taking measures to limit hearings and proceedings conducted during this time.

policy_summary: The Supreme Court of North Carolina postponed ejectment and foreclosure actions, but does not explicitly stop eviction orders that were already approved.
state_level_legal_summary: The Supreme Court of North Carolina postponed ejectment and foreclosure actions, but does not explicitly stop eviction orders that were already approved.

policy_summary: Petition for: A moratorium on all causes of eviction. Community members who cannot demonstrate a documented loss of income should not suffer during this time. Not all workers, such as subcontractors, gig economy workers, or undocumented workers, can provide proof of loss of wages. No one deserves to be evicted during a pandemic. Every tenant should receive the same level of protection, without exception. Prohibit late fees for any missed payments during the state of emergency. Prohibit landlords from evicting a tenant for rent accrued during the state of emergency. This ensures that a landlord cannot immediately serve an eviction notice once the state of emergency ends. A rent freeze during the state of emergency. If tenants are unable to make rent during the state of emergency, it is unreasonable to expect tenants to sustain a rent increase. Reasonable accommodation, at the conclusion of the crisis, for tenants to pay back any rent due. This must include the option of rent forgiveness.
state_level_legal_summary: Governor Phil Murphy signed an Executive Order on 3/19 that halts removals of residents pursuant to evictions or foreclosure proceedings. The EO does not halt initiation or continuation of eviction and foreclosure proceedings. In addition, the Supreme Court cancelled landlord/tenant calendars until April 26th and suspended evictions. The state senate has passed, and the state assembly is now considering, a bill that would create a temporary rental assistance program. The New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency has suspended rent increases at eligible facilities until the governor's order declaring a state of emergency is withdrawn (and after this there must be 30 days notice). The Assembly is also considering a bill that would require forbearance of residential and commercial mortgages, as well as other loans, and tenant rent upon request.

policy_summary: On March 29, the governor announced a 90-day emergency moratorium on evictions and foreclosures related to defaulting on payments. The directive applies to both residential and commercial tenants. The only exception is for tenants deemed to endanger the public, be engaged in criminal activity, or cause severe property damage. Note that this exception can NOT be used to evict tenants who have been diagnosed with or exposed to COVID-19. Landlords cannot change the locks or put notices ontheir tenant’s doors or mailboxes to scare them into moving out.
state_level_legal_summary: Governor signed an Executive Order on 3/29 that halts eviction proceedings for the duration of the state of emergency, except for eviction judgments that predate the March 12th state of emergency declaration. On 3/31, the Supreme Court responded to the Governor's Executive Order by halting the consideration of most eviction matters. The Governor's order also prohibits late fees for nonpayment.

policy_summary:
Landlords can file for eviction at any time. But no new eviction cases will go to court until 8/29/2020, and tenants do not have to file a response until then. In pending cases, court dates will not be set until 60 days after the trial is requested. Court dates that were already scheduled will also be postponed for at least 60 days. (Note: This policy does not apply to evictions deemed necessary for public health and safety.)

When cases resume, some California tenants will have a defense in court against evictions for non-payment of rent. This ONLY covers tenants who paid rent in March and can show that the reason they couldn't pay in April was related to the COVID-19 pandemic.

policy_summary: Phoenix Mayor Kate Gallego has said the city will pause all financial evictions on city-owned housing.
state_level_legal_summary: The Governor has issued a stay on executing all evictions statewide for tenants who can show 1) that they have suffered a substantial loss of income due to COVID-19, 2) that they or a family member have been ordered to stay in quarantine by a medical professional, or 3) that they have a health condition that makes them more at risk to COVID-19. Evictions proceedings are managed by each Superior Court at the local level. So while evictions actions can't be executed, they can still be filed and managed in court. However, Mohave County Court has allowed judges to delay eviction cases if needed. In Phoenix, all city-owned housing is prohibited from evicting tenants. The state supreme court had tolled all eviction deadlines to 5/1/20.

policy_summary: The Utah Supreme Court activated the Pandemic Response Plan and alloweed local courts to implement their own district pandemic response plans. The Utah Supreme Court ordered district courts to perform all mission-critical functions, which do not seem to include eviction proceedings and allows for remote hearings. The Governor of Utah issued and emergency declaration prohibting enforcement of eviction actions only where the tenant is current on rent payments as of 3/31/20 and has suffered job loss or lost income because of COVID-19. Where tenant's COVID-19 related nonpayment is in question, free mediation is available.

policy_summary: The Stockton COVID-19 Eviction Moratorium Ordinance requires the landlord to demonstrate that the termination of tenancy is for a cause other than the non-payment of rent. The Stockton COVID-19 Eviction Moratorium Ordinance protects tenants who: Are over the age of 65; Have a compromised immune system, heart disease, diabetes, or other serious and chronic medical condition that affects the respiratory system; or, Due to the Coronavirus/COVID-19, and related government emergency measures, have suffered a substantial loss of income and cannot pay rent. The Stockton Eviction Moratorium Ordinance applies to mobilehome tenants and owners. Tenants who are not over the age of 65 or disabled, as defined above, may still qualify for the Stockton COVID-19 Eviction Moratorium Ordinance.  To qualify for the Stockton COVID-19 Eviction Moratorium Ordinance, Stockton tenants must: Demonstrate that the Coronavirus/COVID-19 has impacted them; Provide, in writing, to their landlord a notice of inability to pay rent due to Coronavirus/COVID-19 impact, with supporting documentation or other proof. Under the Stockton COVID-19 Eviction Moratorium Ordinance, impacts include: Job loss; A reduction of compensated work hours; Employer’s business closure; Missing work due to a minor child’s school closure; or, Other similarly-caused reasons resulting in a loss of income related to Coronavirus/COVID-19. Stockton landlords are prohibited from evicting tenants for non-payment of rent.

policy_summary: The city has placed a moratorium on evictions for non-payment of rent for tenants who have lost income because of the pandemic—for example, because their hours were cut, their business closed, they were laid off, or they have extreme medical costs related to COVID-19. To be protected, tenants have 30 days after rent is due to provide written notice to the landlord (including emails or texts) that they cannot pay rent, and must provide documentation to support their claim (such as pay stubs, time cards, proof of medical care or quarantine, or notices from employers or schools). After the moratorium ends, tenants will have six months to make up the rent they couldn't pay during the emergency, and will not have to pay any late fees.

policy_summary: Emergency moratorium on all residential and commercial evictions for tenants who demonstrate COVID-19 related inabilities to pay rents. Residential no-fault evictions are also banned unless necessary for the health and safety of the tenants, neighbors or landlord. Tenants must notify landlords in writing within 7 days before rent is due and provide written documentation of inability to pay within 3 days after. 90-day repayment window for each month in arrears, beginning with the first day following the lifting of the moratorium. Landlords cannot charge late or collection fees. Also imposes a ban on rent increases, except for residential properties exempt under CA Civil Code § 1946.2(e) (e.g., most single family homes).

Further, the tenant must attach documentation of their income disruption or COVID-19 out-of-pocket medical expense, such as a medical bill, paystubs, or letter from an employer indicating that the tenant has suffered reduced hours or lost wages due to the Coronavirus. policy_summary: Emergency Order Establishing a Moratorium on Eviction Enforcement in the City of Somerville for the duration of the COVID-19 emergency. The order, which applies to both residential and commercial evictions and goes into effect immediately, prohibits the physical act of eviction within the city limits so as to provide for the health, safety, and stability of those who live in and serve our community. The Eviction Moratorium does not prevent owners from filing eviction cases or getting what is known as “executions for possession” from the courts. It prohibits “levying,” which is the physical removal of persons and belongings. No landlord and/or owner shall access or seek to access a tenant’s dwelling space for purposes such as general inspections, displaying units to potential future tenants and other non-critical activities. A landlord may only access a tenant’s dwelling space to make repairs requested by the tenant, repairs required as a matter of law, or to respond to a life threatening emergency. A tenant may refuse access or entry for non-critical purposes or when adequate social distancing arrangements (at a minimum of six feet) have not been made. policy_summary: Tenants have several protections that are retroactive to 3/4/2020. There is an moratorium and an affirmative defense for no-fault evictions, as well as an affirmative defense for evictions for unauthorized occupants, pets, or nuisance related to the pandemic—for example, if the tenant takes in a family member or pet who has been impacted by the circumstances, and the household becomes noisier than usual as a result. There is also an affirmative defense for evictions for non-payment of rent for one of the following reasons related to the pandemic: (1) loss of income due to a COVID-19 related workplace closure; (2) childcare expenses due to school closures; (3) medical expenses from a member of the household being ill with COVID-19, or caring for a family member with COVID-19; or (4) expenses from complying with government health recommendations. After the order ends, tenants will have 12 months to make up any rent they couldn't pay during the emergency, and will not have to pay any late fees or interest. Tenants and landlords can also agree on a repayment plan (weekly, biweekly, or monthly), but must do so either before the emergency order ends or within 90 days of the first missed rent payment. Los Angeles landlords are required to notify tenants of these protections within 30 days of their effective date. The city also enacted a moratorium on Ellis Act evictions for 60 days after the end of the order. Finally, rent increases are banned for rent-controlled units, and rent increases issued on rent-controlled units on or after 3/30/2020 are invalid.

policy_summary: Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in the Goleta Municipal Code and uncodified regulations, during the period of local emergency declared in response to COVID-19, no landlord shall endeavor to evict a residential or commercial tenant for nonpayment of rent if the tenant demonstrates that the tenant is unable to pay rent due to financial impacts related to COVID-19. A landlord who knows that a tenant cannot pay some or all of the rent temporarily for the reasons set forth above shall not serve a notice pursuant to CCP 1161(2), file or prosecute an unlawful detainer action based on a 3-day pay or quit notice, or otherwise seek to evict for nonpayment of rent. A landlord knows of a tenant’s inability to pay rent within the meaning of this order if the tenant, within 30 days after the date that rent is due, notifies the landlord in writing of lost income and inability to pay full rent due to financial impacts related to COVID19, and provides documentation to support the claim. For purposes of this ordinance, “in writing” includes email or text communications to a landlord or the landlord’s representative with whom the tenant has previously corresponded by email or text. Any medical or financial information provided to the landlord shall be held in confidence, and only used for evaluating the tenant’s claim.

policy_summary: Please note: These protections now cover tenants in Los Angeles County who live in an unincorporated area or in a city that has not passed another ordinance. There is a rent freeze retroactive to 3/4/2020. Rent increases are prohibited on residential properties, including mobile homes. Landlords also may not impose new "pass-throughs" (charging tenants to make up the cost of various fees or capital improvements.) Tenants and mobile home owners have an affirmative defense on 1) no-fault evictions, except those deemed necessary for health and safety; 2) evictions for non-payment of rent for tenants who can't afford to pay because of the pandemic; and 3) evictions based on unauthorized occupants, pets, or nuisance related to the pandemic (for example, if a tenant has to take in a family member or pet and there is additional noise as a result.) These defenses can be used retroactively for evictions filed since 3/4/2020. To be protected against eviction for non-payment of rent, tenants must notify their landlords within 7 days after rent is due that they can't afford to pay. If tenants cannot provide documentation to support their claim, they may submit a self-certification instead, which landlords are required to accept. After the order ends, tenants will have 12 months to make up any rent they couldn't pay during the emergency, and will not have to pay interest or late fees. The county encourages landlords to agree to a repayment plan. The order explicitly bans landlords and their agents from harassing or intimidating tenants based on any of the issues described here. The Los Angeles County Development Authority will extend deadlines for housing assistance recipients and applicants to turn in any documents related to their eligibility. The county is developing a plan to transition adults over 65 who are either unhoused or living in temporary housing into either interim or permanent housing.

policy_summary: The Massachusetts legislature passed, and the governor signed, a model COVID-19 eviction moratorium on April 17, 2020. The emergency legislation will be in effect until 45 days after the governor's emergency declaration ends, or for 120 days, whichever is sooner. It freezes all five stages of evictions, applies to commercial, residential real estate and foreclosure. Landlords would be prohibited from terminating a tenancy and giving tenants a notice to quit. In addition, landlords and mortgagors are prohibited from issuing late fees and reporting to credit agencies where a nonpayment is due to COVID-19 financial hardship. Currently, the State-Level housing court order suspends eviction and/or foreclosure cases and prevents new judgments from being issued until May 4. Deadlines are also tolled until that date. The Housing Court shall not accept and docket any filing(s), decisions, orders, and other documents in “non-essential eviction” (summary process) matters, including such filings, decisions, orders, and other documents that are not expressly prohibited by the Moratorium Legislation. The following filings in summary process cases, however, shall be accepted and allowed by the court: (1) motions to continue; (2) motions to vacate a default judgment entered since March 1, 2020; (3) motions to vacate a dismissal for failure to appear entered since March 1, 2020; and (4) motions to stay an execution. In addition, the court shall accept and, where necessary, docket the following filings in summary process cases: (1) a notice of appearance; (2) original summonses and complaints in previously electronically-filed cases; (3) a notice of voluntary dismissal; (4) a satisfaction of judgment; and (5) original executions. As set forth in the Moratorium Legislation, “a deadline or time period for action by a party to a non-essential eviction . . ., whether such deadline or time period was established before or after [April 20, 2020], including, but not limited to, a date to answer a complaint, appeal a judgment or levy upon an execution for possession or a money judgment, shall be tolled” until such time as the Moratorium Legislation expires.

policy_summary: The Governor's Executive Order 20-13 creates a temporary moratorium on certain evictions and terminations of rental agreements and leases in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.  During the moratorium, the State of Oregon has prohibited landlords of residential properties from taking any action, judicial or otherwise, for reasons of non-payment of rent, late charges, utility charges, or any other service charge or fee. Nothing in the order relieves a tenant of the obligation to pay rent, utility charges or any other service charges or fees, except for late charges or penalties arising from nonpayment during this period which are specifically waived during the moratorium. During this moratorium, any residential or non-residential tenant who is or will be unable to pay the full rent when due under a rental agreement or lease, shall notify the landlord as soon as reasonably possible; and shall make partial rent payments to the extent the tenant is financially able to do so.

The Governor's order also prohibits charging late fees. Most counties and some cities have also limited the eviction moratorium to non-payment cases, and a few have extended it to no-cause evictions. Under the Chief Judge's order, while hearings and proceedings for civil cases are generally postponed, the cases with statutory or constitutional mandates requiring them to be held during the moratorium period will still continue. All judicial districts have postponed jury trials and are taking measures to limit hearings and proceedings conducted during this time.

policy_summary: Clark County Superior Court banned non-emergency evictions. No 14-Day Late Payment Notices. Residential landlords are prohibited from serving a notice of unlawful detainer for default payment of rent related to such property under RCW 59.12.030(3). No No-Cause Termination Notices. Residential landlords are prohibited from issuing a 20-day notice for unlawful detainer related to such property under RCW 59.12.030(2), unless the landlord attaches an affidavit attesting that the action is believed necessary to ensure the health and safety of the tenant or other individuals.  No Unlawful Detainer Actions/Evictions may be filed for nonpayment of rent. Residential landlords are prohibited from initiating judicial action seeking a writ of restitution involving a dwelling unit if the alleged basis for the writ is the failure of the tenant or tenants to timely pay rent. This prohibition includes, but is not limited to, an action under Chapters 59.12 or RCW 59.18 RCW.  Law Enforcement may not assist in the nonpayment of rent evictions. Local law enforcement is prohibited from serving or otherwise acting on eviction orders that are issued solely for default payment of rent related to such property. Nothing in this Proclamation is intended to prohibit local law enforcement from acting on orders of eviction issued for other reasons, including but not limited to waste, nuisance or commission of a crime on the premises.

state_level_legal_summary: The Judicial Council of California adopted emergency rules preventing the issuance of summons and the entry of default in all foreclosure and eviction cases, including commercial, unless there is a threat to public health. The rules also postpone trials for at least 60 days. The Governor has issued an executive order banning the enforcement of eviction orders, and tolling response time for new eviction complaints, for renters affected by COVID-19 through May 31, 2020. Many county superior courts are tolling deadlines via emergency order.

The Swedish Tenants’ Association has been receiving signals of an increased worry among its members who fear they will not be able to make rent payments on time (or at all) due to sudden loss of income. The association has therefore advocated for a national tenants’ fund and rent reductions. According to the chairwoman of the association, Marie Linder, those who are most likely to be heavily affected by the crisis (e.g. those working in hotels, restaurants, or the tourism sector more broadly) are also more likely to be renting. Martin Hofverberg, Chief Economist at the Swedish Tenants’ Association, has also suggested increasing the housing allowance in light of the current situation. This is a solution that is shared by the Property Owners’ Association’s CEO Reinhold Lennebo, who agrees that national policy has often prioritised homeownership over tenancy.
The Swedish Association of Property Owners recommend voluntary measures to be decided on a case-by-case basis and at the discretion of the property owner, including:  Collect rents as per usual but suspend the automatic conversion of overdue payments into debt collection; Meet with tenants who have been financially impacted by the outbreak on an individual basis and decide together what to do about rent payments in coming months; Convert the portion of the rent that cannot be paid at this time into a debt and agree on a payment plan for this debt with the tenant in question; Avoid general (all-encompassing) rent reductions and prioritise finding solutions on a case-by-case basis. 
There are existing protections that come into play: In case of serious illness: For tenants who fall ill from covid-19 there are protections under Swedish tenancy law (hyreslagen) that allow the tenant to keep their tenancy despite late rent, on the grounds of illness. This applies when the tenant is prevented from paying rent as a direct consequence of the illness (for example due to intensive care) and if the tenant is committed to paying rent as soon as possible. In case of sudden loss of income: For people who experience a sudden and unforeseeable loss of income, due to illness or loss of employment, there are support mechanisms in place to ensure this person’s continued social welfare. Per the Swedish Social Services Act (socialtjänstlagen), it is a municipal responsibility to ensure citizens’ material security, which includes financial assistance for rent payments. Paid “disease carrier” leave (Smittbärarpenning): up to 80% of income (but difficult to see how this can be used for such an unexpectedly large number of people).

Scores of Ethiopian families are at risk of contracting the new coronavirus after authorities demolished their makeshift houses and left them homeless, human rights groups said on Wednesday. Authorities in the capital began destroying the informal settlements near Bole International Airport in February. They say the settlement in Addis Ababa, home to more than 1,000 people, is illegal. Residents - mostly casual labourers who have lost their jobs due to COVID-19 restrictions - say they bought the land in 2007 and have the documents to prove it. "Having a home is critical to protecting oneself from COVID-19, stopping its spread and recovering from it," said Deprose Muchena, Amnesty International's Director for East and Southern Africa.

state_level_legal_summary: The Judicial Council of California adopted emergency rules preventing the issuance of summons and the entry of default in all foreclosure and eviction cases, including commercial, unless there is a threat to public health. The rules also postpone trials for at least 60 days. The Governor has issued an executive order banning the enforcement of eviction orders, and tolling response time for new eviction complaints, for renters affected by COVID-19 through May 31, 2020. This order still allows for local governments to pass their own stricter eviction bans. Since the Governor had previously issued an order giving local governments authority to halt evictions, slow foreclosures, and protect against utility shutoffs, several local governments have adopted coronavirus-specific eviction restrictions. Most of these require tenants to provide documentation to verify that they are unable to pay rent due to financial impacts related to COVID-19. Many county superior courts are tolling deadlines via emergency order.
